bcl:definition.bcl:text: Act means the Health Professions Act;
drug means a drug specified in Schedule I, IA, II or IV of the Drug Schedules Regulation, B.C. Reg. 9/98;
medical assistance in dying means the following:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: by a medical practitioner to a person who requests the substance, and
that is intended to cause the death of the person who requested the substance;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the prescription or provision of a substance

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: by a medical practitioner to a person who requests the substance, and
that the person who requested the substance may administer to himself or herself for the purpose of causing his or her own death;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: medicine means the health profession in which a person provides the services of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: assessment and management of the physical or mental condition of an individual or group of individuals at any stage of the biological life cycle, including the prenatal and postmortem periods,
prevention and treatment of physical and mental diseases, disorders and conditions,

bcl:definition.bcl:text: osteopathic physician means a registrant who is authorized under the bylaws to practise medicine as an osteopathic physician;
registrant means a registrant who is authorized under the bylaws to practise medicine;
sell has the same meaning as in the Pharmacy Operations and Drug Scheduling Act.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The name of the college responsible for carrying out the objects of the Act in respect of medicine is "College of Physicians and Surgeons of British Columbia".

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The following titles are reserved for exclusive use by registrants:
The titles "osteopath" and "osteopathic physician" are reserved for exclusive use by osteopathic physicians.
This section does not prevent a person from using

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the title "physician", "surgeon" or "doctor" in a manner authorized by another enactment that regulates a health profession, or
an academic or educational designation that the person is entitled to use.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A registrant in the course of practising medicine may perform any restricted activity.

Only a registrant may provide a service of medicine as set out in this regulation if, on the day before this section comes into force, the provision of the same service by anyone other than a person authorized under the Medical Practitioners Act was prohibited.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Limits or conditions on services and restricted activities

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A registrant may sell a drug only if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: standards, limits or conditions have been established, under section 19 (1) (k) or (l) of the Act, respecting the selling of drugs by registrants, and
the registrant has received written permission from the board to sell drugs in accordance with the standards, limits or conditions described in paragraph (a).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A registrant may provide the service of medical assistance in dying only in accordance with the standards, limits and conditions established by the board for the provision of the service of medical assistance in dying.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The college is authorized to establish, under section 19 (1) (i) of the Act, the following classes of registrants:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a class of restricted registrants, for the purposes of section 20 (4.2) of the Act;
a class of provisional registrants, for the purposes of section 20 (4.3) of the Act.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The college is designated for the purposes of section 16 (2) (f) of the Act.
Part 4 of the Act applies to medicine.

reg:content.reg:provisionsnote: [Provisions relevant to the enactment of this regulation: Health Professions Act, R.S.B.C. 1996, c. 183, s. 12 (2).]
